results.title: Shimmer in the city (A)
results.creator_credit: Special Broadcasting Service Corporation and Amanda Hickey
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.

results.title: Shiloh 2: Shiloh Season
results.creator_credit: Utopia Pictures, Carl Borack, Dale Rosenbloom and Sandy Tung
results.brief_description: Marty Preston (Zachary Browne) is a well-meaning 12-year-old who adopts Shiloh, a beagle who was treated cruelly by his first master, a bitter alcoholic named Judd (Scott Wilson). However, when Judd is hurt in a car accident, Marty realises Judd may have lost one of the only friends he ever had, even if he did mistreat Shiloh. With help from his parents Marty tries to get Judd back on his feet both physically and emotionally, and learns a lot of hard lessons about growing up in the process.

results.title: Shiloh
results.creator_credit: Utopia Pictures, Zeta Entertainment, Zane W. Levitt and Dale Rosenbloom
results.brief_description: Blake Heron stars as Marty Preston, an average kid who lives in an average American small town with his Mum and his mailman Dad (Michael Moriarty). One day Marty finds an injured beagle that’s run away from its abusive owner. Kindly neighbour Doc Wallace (Rod Steiger) tends to the dog’s wounds, but Marty’s father explains that they must return the dog to its rightful owner. Marty knows that Shiloh belongs to someone else, but he is determined to save the dog from more neglect. Against the wishes of his father, Marty risks everything to make the dog his own. This is a story of determination and strength, based on the children’s book of the same name by Phyllis Reynolds Naylor.

results.title: Shifting Sands: from sand to celluloid continued...(A)
results.brief_description: This video contains six short films about the lives of Aboriginal Australians living in today’s society. “Tears”, directed by Ivan Sen, is the story of a teenage couple as they walk from their northern mission station to a bus stop and await a new life with the girl’s father, who perhaps doesn’t know they are coming and who probably doesn’t care anyway. “My colour, your kind”, directed by Danielle McLean, is the journey through and to uncertainty of an albino Aboriginal girl who escapes from a severe Catholic mission to trek barefoot in a nightie across the outback. “Passing through”, directed by Mark Olive, a young family on their way to visit relatives pass through an old gold mining town. As the woman begins to delve into memories of her childhood, the family leave to continue their journey. Has she missed the opportunity to discover the secrets of the past? “Promise”, directed by Mitch Torres, is the tale of an old woman overseeing her grand-daughter making damper when she is asked how it came to be that she was betrothed at a young age. “My bed, your bed”, directed by Erica Glynn, in an isolated desert community, the time has come for two young people promised to each other under traditional law to move in together. Things don’t run as smoothly as they might. “Grace”, directed by Wesley Enoch, Grace is a middle-aged woman, living a comfortable life but when she returns to the mission where she grew up for the funeral of her sister she is confronted by the family she never met.

results.title: Shifting sands
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Battle for the planet”.
The program is presented by William Hinton, a Nebraska grazier and frequent visitor to China. One third of the world’s crop and grazing land is affected by desertification. 850 million people earn their living in these regions. In China, the problem is rapidly growing. Large parts of the north and west, especially in Inner Mongolia, are badly affected. Hinton argues that there are several causes of desertification: an increase in the human population, more intensive grazing and a meat pricing system which encourages farmers to keep older animals. The result is that sandy areas break out in a few small isolated areas and eventually link up to form a huge dune which is whipped along by the wind at the rate of metres by the day. The Chinese are trying several ways to reverse the process: green belts of trees, irrigation and enclosures. However Hinton argues convincingly that the dunes will beat these measures and only a change in animal husbandry and the meat pricing system will achieve the desired end.

results.title: Shichinin no Samurai = Seven Samurai
results.creator_credit: Shojiro Motoki, Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Kurosawa’s peerless action drama overthrew fixed notions of genre in placing the chambara (sword-play) film within a meaningful past and tempering social drama (jidai-geki) with comedy. It translated into the ethos of the Western as The Magnificient Seven. The position of the ronin, defenders of civilised society yet placed outside it, is not dissimilar to that of the Westerner - a humanist existentialism crossing cultural boundaries. However, in contrast to the Western where history is most often a pretext, Kurosawa locates his characters firmly in a specific historical context - the chaotic period of civil wars in the 16th century before the relative peace of the Tokugawa period (1600-1868). Also available on 16mm, LD and VHS.

Credits: Director, Akira Kurosawa ; producer, Sojiro Motoki ; script, Akira Kurosawa, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni ; photography, Asaichi Nakai ; [music, Fumio Hayasaka].
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Takashi Shimura, Keiko Tsushima, Kamatari Fujiwara.

results.title: Shestaya chast mira = The Sixth part of the world
results.brief_description:
A celebration of the resources of the Soviet Union, by the pioneering Russian film-maker and avant-gardist, Dziga Vertov - a free-flowing sequence of images drawn from all corners of the country showing the wealth of the Soviet people who have overthrown the capitalist class. This film contrasts Soviet industriousness with the decadence of foreign capitalists; and Soviet plenty and freedom with the poverty and slavery of the people in capitalist countries. Dziga Vertov was the founder of the Soviet documentary and headed a group of experimental documentarists who took the name Kinoki, or Kino-Eyes. As a militant theorist he proclaimed the supremacy of what would now be called Cinema-Verite. His films and his theoretical writings have had an enormous and lasting influence on world cinema. ‘The Sixth Part of the World’ is Vertov’s lyrical cinema poem to the vast expanses of the Soviet Union, grand, complicated and exotic.

Credits: Director, writer, editing, Dziga Vertov ; photography, Mikhail Kaufman.

results.title: Sherman's march: a meditation on the possibility of romantic love in the South during an era of nuclear weapons proliferation
results.brief_description: A journey by the filmmaker through the South follows the route of the Union’s General Sherman who carried on the war against the civilian population of the Confederacy, then largely female. Along the way McElwee is confronted by the mysteries of Southern womanhood in his encounters with eight women. His dreams are haunted by the spectre of nuclear war and he encounters signs of its pervasiveness along the way. McElwee assesses the state of his movie as he goes along, on the soundtrack and in a series of soliloquies to the camera.
